questions.text: In the context of polio in India, which of the following statements is correct regarding the different types of poliovirus (Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3)?

choices.text: India has successfully eradicated Type 1, but Type 2 and Type 3 still remain a threat.
Type 2 poliovirus has been eradicated globally, and India is free from both Type 2 and Type 3 poliovirus, with efforts ongoing to eradicate Type 1.
All three types of poliovirus are still prevalent in India, requiring continued vaccination efforts.
World Health Organization declared India polio-free in 2014, and no Type 1, Type 2, or Type 3 poliovirus cases have been reported.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) World Health Organization declared India polio-free in 2014, and no Type 1, Type 2, or Type 3 poliovirus cases have been reported

 

Explanation:
India was declared polio-free by the WHO in 2014.

  • The last reported case of Type 1 poliovirus in India was in January 2011.
  • Type 2 poliovirus was eradicated globally in 1999.
  • The last detected Type 3 case was in Nov 2012 and declared eradicated in Oct 2019.

 

Current efforts are focused on

  • Preventing any resurgence of Type 1 poliovirus
  • Regular surveillance
  • Maintaining high vaccination coverage prevents the outbreak and ensures the country remains polio-free.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the differences between the Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) and the Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV)?

choices.text: OPV is a killed formalized virus vaccine administered subcutaneously, while IPV is a live attenuated virus vaccine taken orally.
OPV provides both humoral and intestinal immunity and is effective in controlling epidemics, while IPV provides only humoral immunity and is not useful in controlling epidemics.
OPV requires less stringent storage and transport conditions compared to IPV.
Both OPV and IPV have the same shelf life and risk of vaccine-associated paralytic poliomyelitis (VAPP).

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) OPV provides both humoral and intestinal immunity and is effective in controlling epidemics, while IPV provides only humoral immunity and is not useful in controlling epidemics.

Explanation:

Vaccination against poliovirus involves the use of two distinct types of vaccines: Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) and Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV).

Differences between OPV and IPV:

Characteristic

OPV (Sabin)

IPV (Salk)

Type of Vaccine

Live attenuated virus

Killed (inactivated) virus

Mode of Administration

Oral

Intramuscular (IM) or Subcutaneous (SC)

Type of Immunity

Humoral + Intestinal

Humoral

Prevention of

Paralysis + Intestinal re-infection

Paralysis

Control of Epidemics

Effective

Less effective

Storage, Transport & Shelf Life

Requires sub-zero temperatures, Shorter shelf life

Less stringent conditions, Longer shelf life

Vaccine-Associated Paralytic Poliomyelitis (VAPP)

1 per 2.7 million first doses (higher in subsequent doses)

Zero incidences

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately differentiates between OPV and IPV in terms of their composition and the measurement of vaccine strength?

choices.text: OPV contains live attenuated poliovirus, and the quantity of antigen per dose measures its strength. IPV contains killed poliovirus, and the potency of the live virus measures its strength.
OPV contains killed poliovirus, and its strength is measured by the quantity of antigen per dose. IPV contains live attenuated poliovirus, and the potency of the live virus measures its strength.
OPV contains live attenuated poliovirus, and the potency of the live virus measures its strength. IPV contains killed poliovirus, and the quantity of antigen per dose measures its strength.
OPV and IPV both contain live attenuated poliovirus, and their strengths are measured by the quantity of antigen per dose.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) OPV contains live attenuated poliovirus, and the potency of the live virus measures its strength. IPV contains killed poliovirus, and the quantity of antigen per dose measures its strength.

Explanation:

Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) contains live attenuated strains of all three poliovirus serotypes (type 1, type 2, and type 3).

The strength of OPV - the potency of the live attenuated virus - ability to induce an immune response that produces antibodies against the 3 poliovirus serotypes.

  • Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3: The potency of OPV for each serotype is measured in terms of the tissue culture infectious dose 50 (TCID50), which reflects the amount of virus required to infect 50% of the cell cultures.

                                                                                                                                    Composition of OPV:

Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) contains killed (inactivated) poliovirus strains of all three serotypes (type 1, type 2, and type 3).

The strength of IPV- amount of antigen (inactivated virus) present in the vaccine - quantified in D-antigen units for each serotype - vaccine's ability to induce protective antibodies.

Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3: Each serotype's strength is specified by the minimum D-antigen units required per dose to ensure immunogenicity.

                                                                                                                                      Composition of IPV:

questions.text: Which of the following Hepatitis B virus (HBV) markers is correctly paired with its significance?

choices.text: HBsAg + HBeAg + IgM - Indicates acute infection with high infectivity
HBsAg + HBeAg + IgG- Indicates acute infection in recovery phase
Anti-HBc only - Indicates immunity due to vaccination
Anti-HBs + HBeAg + IgG - Indicates recovery from infection in recent past

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) - Indicates active infection

Explanation:

Hepatitis B is a viral infection that affects the liver and can lead to acute and chronic diseases.

Diagnosis and management of Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection rely on detecting specific viral markers in the blood. These markers help determine the phase of disease, the degree of infectivity, and the patient's immune status.

Understanding the significance of each marker is crucial for accurate diagnosis and effective treatment.

                                                                                                                        Markers of Hepatitis-B Infection:

Marker

Indicates

HBsAg (Option A)

Active HBV infection, either acute or chronic

HBsAb (anti-HBs) (Option B)

Immunity to HBV (recovery and subsequent immunity to past infection or vaccination) - last to appear

HBcAg

The most accurate index of active viral replication

HBcAb IgM (anti-HBc IgM)

Acute HBV infection

HBcAb IgG (anti-HBc IgG) (Option C)

Past or chronic HBV infection

HBeAg (Option D)

Active viral replication and high infectivity

HBeAb (anti-HBe)

Seroconversion, usually in chronic infection, and lower infectivity

questions.text: Which of the following correctly represents the composition of the new reduced osmolarity Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS)?

choices.text: Sodium: 75 mmol/L, Glucose: 75 mmol/L, Potassium: 20 mmol/L, Chloride: 65 mmol/L, Citrate: 10 mmol/L, Total Osmolarity: 245 mOsm/L
Sodium: 70 mmol/L, Glucose: 70 mmol/L, Potassium: 25 mmol/L, Chloride: 65 mmol/L, Citrate: 15 mmol/L, Total Osmolarity: 245 mOsm/L
Sodium: 75 mmol/L, Glucose: 75 mmol/L, Potassium: 20 mmol/L, Chloride: 60 mmol/L, Citrate: 15 mmol/L, Total Osmolarity: 245 mOsm/L
Sodium: 70 mmol/L, Glucose: 70 mmol/L, Potassium: 20 mmol/L, Chloride: 60 mmol/L, Citrate: 10 mmol/L, Total Osmolarity: 230 mOsm/L

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sodium: 75 mmol/L, Glucose: 75 mmol/L, Potassium: 20 mmol/L, Chloride: 65 mmol/L, Citrate: 10 mmol/L, Total Osmolarity: 245 mOsm/L

Explanation:

Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) therapy is based on the principle that glucose facilitates salt and water absorption in the intestine, thereby restoring electrolyte and fluid balance.

WHO and UNICEF recommend the use of reduced osmolarity ORS due to the following advantages:

  • Lower sodium and glucose concentrations decrease osmolarity, reducing the risk of adverse effects associated with hypertonicity.
  • Trisodium citrate enhances sodium and water absorption, resulting in reduced stool output.

Composition of Reduced Osmolarity ORS:

Component

Glucose anhydrous

Total osmolarity

Potassium chloride

1.5

Trisodium citrate, dihydrate

2.9

Total weight

20.5

questions.text: Which of the following is an additional ion present in ReSoMal?

choices.text: Sodium
Calcium
Potassium
Magnesium

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Magnesium

Explanation:

ReSoMal (Rehydration Solution for Malnutrition) is specifically designed to rehydrate severely malnourished children suffering from diarrhea-related dehydration.

Comparison of ReSoMal vs Standard ORS:

Component

ReSoMal

Standard ORS

Sodium

45

90

Potassium

40

20

Chloride

70

80

Citrate

7

10

Magnesium

3

-

Zinc

0.3

-

Copper

0.045

-

Glucose

125

111

Osmolarity

300

311

Severely malnourished children often have imbalanced electrolyte levels. ReSoMal is specifically formulated to address these imbalances, providing lower sodium and higher potassium and magnesium levels compared to standard ORS.

  • The lower sodium content in ReSoMal minimizes the risk of hypernatremia.
  • Additional nutrients like magnesium, zinc, and copper support overall recovery and immune function.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Super ORS?

choices.text: Super ORS instead of mono sugars, is based on complex sugars such as rice or amino acids like glycine or alanine.
It provides more calories (180 kcal/L) and is intended to cause weight gain in the malnourished.
Super ORS has a long shelf life and can be prepared once a week.
It helps reduce stool output, the frequency of stools, and the duration of diarrhea.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Super ORS has a long shelf life and can be prepared once a week.

Explanation:

Super ORS has a short shelf life of less than 10 hours and needs to be freshly prepared 2-3 times a day.

Advantages and Disadvantages of Super ORS:

Advantages

Disadvantages

Provides rehydration

Short shelf life (< 10 hours)

Reduces stool output

Needs to be prepared freshly 2-3 times a day

Reduces frequency of stools

  

Reduces duration of diarrhea

  

Provides 180 kcal/L, contributing towards weight gain

  

Useful for malnourished children

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the components of Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS)?

choices.text: The glucose dependent sodium and water absorption is the principle behind replacing glucose and sodium in 1:1 molar ratio in the WHO-ORS.
Potassium improves the absorption of sodium and water by enhancing concentration gradient for sodium.
Trisodium citrate improves the shelf life of ORS, making it more stable.
Trisodium citrate reduces stool output by 25% and enhances sodium and water absorption.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Potassium improves the absorption of sodium and water by enhancing the concentration gradient for sodium.

Explanation:

Potassium's primary role is to replace the essential ions lost during diarrhea and vomiting, not to enhance the concentration gradient for sodium absorption.

Component

Role

Glucose
  • Allows intestines to absorb sodium, dragging water into intestinal cells and the body for rehydration.

Potassium
  • Replaces essential ions lost during diarrhea and vomiting, helping to maintain electrolyte balance.

Trisodium Citrate
  • It improves the shelf life of ORS, making it more stable.
  • Helps reduce stool output by 25%.
  • Enhances absorption of sodium and water.

Sodium Chloride
  • It provides the necessary sodium to help absorb water and maintain fluid balance.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old child presents with 2-3 episodes of diarrhea and on examination for skin returns quickly when pinched, there is no excessive thirst or refusal to drink fluids and the child accepts fluids or food orally without any difficulty.

Which of the following management steps is incorrect for treating the child at home concerning the clinical symptoms?

choices.text: Counsel the mother to give extra fluids and continue feeding.
Provide frequent small sips of 50-100 ml of fluid after each loose stool.
Mandatory administration of ORS solution every 2 hours to prevent signs and symptoms of dehydration.
Give zinc supplementation of 20mg for 14 days.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mandatory administration of ORS solution every 2 hours to prevent signs and symptoms of dehydration.

Explanation:

ORS solution is unnecessary if the child suffers from mild diarrhea and there are no signs of dehydration. In mild diarrhea, fluids/ORS should be given according to the child’s needs.

Plan

Criteria

Management Steps

A

Mild diarrhea, no dehydration
  • Counsel the mother to give extra fluids, continue feeding, give zinc supplements, follow up.
  • Fluids: Small sips (50-100 ml after each loose stool for children up to 2 years, 100-200 ml for children over 2 years).
  • Zinc: 20 mg tab for two months to 5 years (dissolve in breast milk or ORS for infants).

B

Moderate dehydration
  • Administer ORS in a clinical setting: Amount based on weight and age (e.g., 450-800 ml for children 6-10 kg).
  • Reassess hydration status after 4 hours.

C

Severe dehydration
  • If possible, provide immediate IV fluids; otherwise, start ORS by mouth while setting up the IV. The dosage is 100 ml/kg Ringer's Lactate or normal saline over 1-5 hours, depending on the patient's age.
  • Reassess every 1-2 hours, switch to ORS as the child stabilizes, and continue monitoring and using the appropriate hydration method (IV/NG/ORS).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding cholera?

choices.text: The predominant serotype of cholera in India is the El Tor biotype of Vibrio cholerae O1.
holera is no longer a notifiable disease locally and nationally, but remains notifiable internationally.
The oral cholera vaccine Dukoral includes a recombinant cholera toxin B subunit and is suitable for children under two years.
Shanchol and mORCVAX are oral cholera vaccines based on serogroups O1 and O139, used for individuals over 1 year of age.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The oral cholera vaccine Dukoral includes a recombinant cholera toxin B subunit and is suitable for children under 2 years.

Explanation:-

  • Dukoral is an oral inactivated cholera vaccine that contains killed V. cholerae O1 and a recombinant B subunit of cholera toxin.
     
  • However, Dukoral is not recommended for children under 2 years of age.
     
  • Hence, the statement is incorrect.
     

Cholera Vaccines and Use

Vaccine

Contains

Age Group

Notes

Dukoral

Killed V. cholerae O1 + recombinant B subunit

≥2 years

Requires buffer; provides short-term protection

Shanchol

Killed V. cholerae O1 and O139

≥1 year

Used in endemic/outbreak settings

mORCVAX

Killed V. cholerae O1 and O139

≥1 year

Similar to Shanchol


 

The predominant serotype of cholera in India is the El Tor biotype of Vibrio cholerae O1. (Option A):
Correct. El Tor biotype is the major cause of cholera outbreaks in India and many parts of Asia.
 

 

Cholera is no longer a notifiable disease locally and nationally, but remains notifiable internationally. (Option B):
Correct. As per the International Health Regulations (IHR), cholera is still internationally notifiable, even if it’s not locally reportable in some countries.
 

 

Shanchol and mORCVAX are oral cholera vaccines based on serogroups O1 and O139, used for individuals over 1 year of age. (Option D):
Correct. Both are killed whole-cell vaccines effective against O1 and O139 strains and are administered to individuals aged ≥1 year.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with fever, abdominal pain, and a rash. Blood cultures confirm typhoid fever. The pediatrician discusses vaccination for family members for future typhoid prevention. Which of the following statements about typhoid vaccines is incorrect?

choices.text: Ty21a is a live vaccine administered orally and recommended for individuals over 5 years old.
The Vi polysaccharide vaccine is a killed vaccine given subcutaneously or intramuscularly, suitable for children over 2 years old.
Ty21a requires a single dose shot that is repeated every 3 years.
The Vi polysaccharide vaccine does not elicit adequate immune responses in children aged less than 2 years.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ty21a requires a single dose shot that is repeated every 3 years.

Explanation:

Ty21a is an oral typhoid vaccine and requires a three-dose regimen (1, 3, 5 days) repeated every 3 years, while Vi polysaccharide is a IM/SC vaccine and requires a single dose shot that is repeated every 3 years.

Feature

Ty21a Vaccine

Vi Polysaccharide Vaccine

Typhoid  conjugate vaccine 

Type

Live-attenuated vaccine

Killed (inactivated) vaccine

Inactivated (killed) vaccine

Route of Administration

Oral

Subcutaneous/Intramuscular

Intramuscular 

Age Recommendation

>5 years

>2 years

>6 months

Dosage Regimen

3-dose regimen (1, 3, 5 days), repeated every 3 years

Single dose, repeated every 3 years

Single dose

Immunity Development

Develops after 7 days

Develops after 7 days

 Develops after 7 days and high seroconversion by 4 weeks

Effectiveness in Young Children

Not recommended for children under 5 years

Does not elicit adequate immune response in children <2 years

 Not recommended for children below 6 months

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding typhoid?

choices.text: Typhoid is endemic in India.
Man is the only reservoir for typhoid infection.
Diagnosis of typhoid includes blood culture in the 1st week, Widal test in the 2nd week, and fecal and urine cultures in the 3rd and 4th weeks.
Somatic O Antigen is higher in the post-vaccination phase, and Flagellar H Antigen is higher in the post-infection phase.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Somatic O Antigen is higher in the post-vaccination phase, and Flagellar H Antigen is higher in the post-infection phase.

Explanation:

The Somatic O Antigen is higher in the post-infection phase, and the Flagellar H Antigen is higher in the post-vaccination phase.

Epidemiological Data
  • Typhoid is endemic in India. The causative agent is Salmonella typhi. (Option A)

Reservoir
  • Man is the only reservoir for typhoid infection. (Option B)

Sources of Infection
  • Primary: Feces > Urine
  • Secondary: Contaminated water, food, fingers, fomites.

Carriers
  • Convalescent carriers: Excrete bacilli for 6-8 weeks.
  • Chronic carriers: Excrete bacilli for >1 year.

Mode of Transmission
  • Feco-oral route.

Incubation Period
  • 10-14 days.

Clinical Features
  • Early phase: Fever, paradoxical bradycardia, pea soup diarrhea.
  • Late phase: Splenomegaly, rose spots.

Diagnostic Modalities
(Option C)
  • 1st week: Blood culture
  • 2nd week: Widal test
  • 3rd & 4th weeks: Fecal and urine cultures.

Treatment
  • Fluoroquinolones, azithromycin, ceftriaxone, cefixime.
